work.p: This manuscript is similar to a line in the manuscript poem, unpublished in Whitman's lifetime, titled "Pictures": "And there, singular, on ocean waves, downward, buoyant, swift, over the waters, an occupied coffin floating." The first several lines of the poem (not including this line) were revised and published as "My Picture-Gallery" in The American in October 1880. The poem was later published in Leaves of Grass as part of the "Autumn Rivulets" cluster (1881, p. 310).

titleStmt.title: Downward, buoyant
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This fragmentary manuscript probably dates to the latter half of the 1850s. It bears a version of a line incorporated in the manuscript poem "Pictures," which Whitman probably created between 1855 and 1860. Another version of the line is inscribed in the notebook "I know a rich capitalist," which Whitman apparently used between about 1854 and 1860. On the reverse side of the leaf are lines that contributed to the 1860 poem eventually titled "Starting from Paumanok."

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: How can there be immortality
bibl.orgName: Papers of Walt Whitman (MSS 3829), Clifton Waller Barrett Library of American Literature, Albert H. Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
A series of draft lines written on the back of this manuscript leaf relate to the poem eventually titled "Starting from Paumanok."

body.l:
Downward, buoyant, On turbid waters, whirling and
rocking and swift buoyant, swift
coffin floats float
